name: AGK-2010
notes: Geotechnical

name: ALRS-1
notes: materials of basalt characteristics taken from a mine in New South Wales are used

name: BH-1/2
notes: Made from pyroclastic material

name: BP-1
notes: Lunar mare simulant Black Point One (BP-1) was discovered during a Desert Research and Technology Studies (Desert RATS) analog test and was collected from a road metal quarry in the Black Point basalt flow in San Francisco Volcanic Field, in northern Arizona[1]. BP-1 was not further processed or modified after its collection from the quarry washing waste, but it has very similar physical properties to lunar soil.

name: CAS-1
institution:
Institute of
Geochemistry,
Chinese Academy of Sciences
notes: General-use mare simulant consisting of low-Ti basalt slag sourced from the volcanic area in Changbai Mountains, China. CLRS-1 appears to be another name for the same simulant.

name: Chenobi
notes: undocumented

name: CSM-CL
notes: Colorado Lava

name: CUG-1A
notes: Demonstrates comparatively lower softening point and can achieve densification with reduced energy input relative to JSC-2

name: CUMT-1
institution: China University of Mining and Technology
notes: Developed to recover properties of lunar regolith and simulate lunar gravity using geotechnical magnetic-similitude-gravity model testing (GMMT) method. Prepared by reproducing the in-situ formation and fragmentation of the lunar matrix. Specialized for use in lunar low gravity simulation and geotechnical engineering-based applications.

name: DNA-1
notes: Formulated to imitate lunar soil samples retrieved in Apollo missions. Contains 75% crystalline phase. Around 30% of cumulative volume overlaps with fly ash particle size range.

name: DNA-1A
notes: Similar in composition to JSC-2A simulant

name: DUST-Y
notes: non-mineralogical silicate dust simulant

name: EAC-1
notes: Geotechnical simulant that imitates most of the physical properties of lunar soil; irrelevant material for high temperature applications

name: EAC-1A
notes: Basanitic sandy silt from a quarry located in the Siebengebirge Volcanic Field, developed for use in the European Lunar Exploration Laboratory (LUNA) facility

name: FJS-1
notes: Developed in Japan from Mount Fuji area basalts

name: FJS-1g
notes: Average luna mare (general), enhanced glass

name: FJS-2
notes: Contains the same basalt as FJS-1 but with olivine added. Developed for JAXA to represent the chemistry, mineralogy and geotechnical properties of mare basalt lunar regolith.

name: FJS-3
notes: Luna mare (High Titanium model)

name: GreenSpar
notes: Average highland anorthosite, An 78-86 (general)

name: JLU-H
notes: consisting of anorthosite and contains some coarse particles up to 50 mm in size

name: JSC-1
notes: Designed to have a high proportion of natural glass, made from welded tuff from a quarry north of Flagstaff, AZ, chosen because it had ~50% friable glass and was available in large quantities, composition only represents some 2-3% of the lunar surface, has only <<1% ilmenite

name: JSC-1A
notes: Used as terrestrial control material in plant growth experiments

name: JSC-1AC
notes: Used in microwave processing studies for high-temperature dielectric properties

name: JSC-1AF
notes: fine particle portion of JSC-1A

name: KIGAM-L1
notes: Korean Lunar Highland Soil Simulant

name: KLS-1
notes: Uses intrusive basalt as raw material, and the chemical composition having high similarity to those of real lunar soil

name: Kohyama
notes: specialized simulant for water and oxygen extraction

name: LCATS-1
notes: Basaltic planetary soil simulant composed of terrestrial basalt

name: LHS-1
notes: lunar regolith simulant used in earthworm colonization experiments for bioengineering approach supporting future crop growth in space

name: LMS-1
notes: lunar mare simulant made by mixing minerals from different places

name: LSS-ISAC-1
notes: Used in MICP (Microbially Induced Carbonate Precipitation) solidification studies, achieved compressive strengths in the range of 3-6 MPa demonstrating moderate solidification efficacy

name: LuNOR
notes:
A novel feature of this simulant is that it contains no
processed mineral concentrates but rather focuses on natural rock using resources
local to Norway

name: LX-M100
notes: basalt base simulant representing one of the Moon's two major bedrock types, serves as foundation for flexible simulant system

name: LX-T100
notes: anorthosite base simulant representing one of the Moon's two major bedrock types, serves as foundation for flexible simulant system

name: MKS-1
notes: intended use unknown

name: MLS-1
notes: First high-Ti simulant proposed by Weiblen et al.
particle_size_distribution: ground into a Particle Size Distribution (PSD) to resemble lunar soil

name: MLS-2
notes: highland simulant made of ground anorthosite from the Duluth Gabbro Complex, Minnesota

name: NAO-1
institution:
National
Astronomical
Observatories,
Chinese Academy of
Sciences
notes: Produced by gabbro which includes large quantity of feldspar (An90). Primary material mined from gabbro located on the north bank of the Yarlung Zangbo River in Tibet. Main components of the gabbro are pyroxene and anorthite.

name: NU-LHT
notes: Part of NU-LHT series, includes NU-LHT-2M variant

name: NU-LHT-1D
notes: dust simulant

name: NU-LHT-1M
notes: Shows segregation and stratification after handling

name: NU-LHT-2C
notes: Breccia simulant variant of the NU-LHT series

name: NU-LHT-2M
availability: out of production and largely out of stock
notes: Did not flow through the orifice under test conditions, showing different flow characteristics compared to other simulants

name: NUW-LHT-5M
notes: Includes synthetic glass to match the Apollo 16 glass chemistry

name: OB-1
notes: developed for the simulation of Apollo 16 anorthositic regolith sample 64500

name: OB-1A
notes: Consisted of 60% Shawmere anorthosite, and 40% glass slag. NASA purchased 500 kg of this simulant.

name: OPR Agglutinate
notes: Agglutinate component made out of any of the above simulants

name: OPRFLCROSS2
notes: Lunar icy regolith simulant

name: OPRH2N
notes: Average highlands, Apollo based (general)- 70% anorthosite, 30% basaltic cinder

name: OPRH3N
notes: 80% anorthosite, 20% basaltic cinder

name: OPRH4N
notes: Highland simulant that is a blend of basalt from the San Francisco volcanic field in Arizona and anorthosite from the Shawmere anorthosite complex in Canada. Designed to replicate the chemical, mineralogical, and geotechnical properties of lunar regolith. Agglutinates can be added (OPRH4W variant available).

name: OPRL2N
notes: Average mare, Apollo based (general)- 90% basaltic cinder, 10% anorthosite

name: OPRL2NT
notes: h-Ti mare, Apollo based (general) - 77% basaltic cinder, 8.6% anorthosite, 14.4% ilmer

name: Oshima
notes: Average luna mare

name: TBG-1
notes: Best fit simulant to Apollo 14 soil R07 with distance d=10.00

name: TLH-0
notes: Represents the anorthositic composition of the lunar highlands. Rich in plagioclase, it offers high albedo and low iron content, ideal for optical, mechanical, and ISRU studies focusing on the Moon’s bright, ancient crustal regions. With a 91.7 out of 100 NASA FoM fidelity score

name: TLM-0
notes: thermal, magnetic, and excavation-related technologies

name: TLS-01
notes: Made from basalt rock from Trad province, designed for biomining extraction of sodium, magnesium, iron, aluminum, titanium and silicon

name: TUBS-H
notes: Produced using a flexible preparation method where basalt is supplemented with minerals or sintered glass to achieve specific objectives

name: TUBS-M
notes: Uses a flexible preparation method where basalt is supplemented with minerals or sintered glass to achieve specific objectives

name: TUBS-T
notes: lunar regolith simulant developed by the Institute of Space Systems (IRAS) at TU Braunschweig

name: UOM-Black
notes: large volume, mechanical

name: UOM-White
notes: large volume, mechanical

name: WHU-1
notes: Prepared based on particle size distribution data from samples returned by the Chang'e-5 mission
